A child with clinical features of rickets did not respond to cholecalciferol therapy. His investigations show:Serum calcium: 10 mg/dL (normal) Serum phosphate: low Parathormone (PTH): normal Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This child has:
  • • Normal calcium → rules out hypocalcemic causes
  • • Low phosphate
  • • Normal PTH
  • • Poor response to vitamin D (cholecalciferol)
  • • This profile is classic for hypophosphatemic rickets, especially X-linked hypophosphatemia, caused by renal phosphate wasting due to elevated FGF23. These patients typically require oral phosphate supplements and active vitamin D analogues (e.g., calcitriol).
  • • Vitamin D–dependent rickets (types 1 and 2) usually show hypocalcemia and high PTH, and may respond to high-dose calcitriol, not cholecalciferol.
  • • Hypoparathyroidism causes low calcium, not seen here.
  • • dRTA presents with metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and often normal or low phosphate but not the current constellation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with bowing of the legs, poor growth, and delayed dentition is diagnosed with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH). Genetic testing confirms a PHEX mutation, and serum studies reveal low phosphate, normal calcium, normal vitamin D, and inappropriately high FGF23 levels. What is the mechanism of action of the most specific treatment for this condition?

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Neutralizes excess fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23)
